file.content:
│   ├── Top-level structure (show from Anthropic blog/images)
│   ├── How it appears in the prompt:
│   │   ├── Model sees: "I have these skills available"
│   │   ├── Model thinks: "I need to acquire this skill"
│   │   ├── Model reads the skill files
│   │   └── Now that knowledge is IN the context window
│   ├── File tree structure:
│   │   ├── SKILL.md (main file)
│   │   ├── references/ (linked docs)
│   │   └── "For this workflow, go to this file"
│   └── Progressive disclosure - only load context when needed
│
├── 07-the-vision/
│   ├── What we're doing with skills = encoding your engineering knowledge
│   ├── First: Agent efficiently does flows you already do
│   ├── Then: Trust builds → queue as background task → just review
│   ├── Goal: Step farther and farther out of the loop
│   ├── REALITY CHECK - Pushback on "10x engineer" myth:
│   │   ├── 10x output is NOT instant transformation
│   │   ├── Reality: 10% faster here, 5% faster there
│   │   ├── These compound over MONTHS
│   │   ├── No magic pill - AI does NOT replace knowledge
│   │   └── You're building TOWARDS that future, not there yet
│   └── Don't "just let AI handle it completely" - but build toward it
│
├── 08-example-skill/
│   ├── Show file tree of Ford's Claude Code config
│   │   └── "I have a lot of skills/commands built out"
│   ├── "This isn't comprehensive - this is how I work"
│   ├── Focus on ONE specific skill [TBD which one]
│   ├── OCCAM'S RAZOR approach to building skills:
│   │   ├── Common mistake: give everything to the agent right out the gate
│   │   ├── This leads to bad skills - flow isn't tested, not based on YOUR flow
│   │   ├── Right approach: Work IN the loop first
│   │   ├── Iterate until you're happy with how it works
│   │   ├── THEN: "How can I take myself out of it?"
│   │   └── Keep it as simple as possible - don't add complexity until you need it
│   ├── Show how I go about making them
│   └── How this standardizes a process you + agent can leverage
│   └── (Light touch, 5-7 min total for skills section)
│
├── 09-key-takeaways/
│   ├── Don't let bad examples blind you - this is coming
│   ├── For skilled engineers, AI is a HUGE force multiplier
│   ├── The Math (makes it a no-brainer):
│   │   ├── Each engineer using ~$1,000/month in tokens (like me)
│   │   ├── 10 engineers = $10,000/month token spend
│   │   ├── Average engineer costs ~$10,000/month
│   │   ├── 40% more effective = value of 4 extra engineers = $40,000/month
│   │   ├── Spend $10K to get $40K value = 4x ROI

--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # This Isn't New

Working with a Junior Engineer

1. You determine what the task should be
2. You hand it off
3. You review the PR
? HOW it gets done? You don't control that

But There's Standardization

- Commit rules
- Tests must pass
- GitHub Actions
- Company protocols
- Documentation
The same docs you'd give a new junior = what you give the LLM

--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # What is a Skill?
📄
Opinionated Markdown Files
A structured way to format documentation that agents can understand
🔍
Self-Discovery
Agent can discover and acquire processes within the skill on-demand
🏛️
Becoming Standard
Anthropic recently released this structure - it's becoming the standard
✅
Not Complicated
You already have the knowledge - skills just encode it properly

tool_input.content:
--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # How Skills Work

The Flow

1.
Model sees: "I have these skills available"
2.
Model thinks: "I need to acquire this skill"
3. Model reads the skill files
4. Knowledge is now IN the context

File Structure

.claude/skills/
my-skill/
SKILL.md
references/
workflow.md
examples.md
Progressive Disclosure
Only load context when needed - keeps the context window lean

tool_input.content:
--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # Example: My Skills Setup
This is how I work - not comprehensive, but practical.
.claude/
settings.json
skills/
agent-session/
commit/
pr-review/
prime/
...
I have a lot of skills/commands built out - each one codifies a workflow I do repeatedly.

What's in a Skill?

SKILL.md
Entry point - describes what the skill does and when to use it
Workflows
Step-by-step processes the agent follows
References
Examples, templates, domain knowledge
This standardizes a process you + agent can leverage

I have a lot of skills/commands built out - each one codifies a workflow I do repeatedly.

What's in a Skill?

SKILL.md
Entry point - describes what the skill does and when to use it
Workflows
Step-by-step processes the agent follows
References
Examples, templates, domain knowledge
This standardizes a process you + agent can leverage

tool_input.content:
--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # Building Skills: Occam's Razor

The Common Mistake

Give everything to the agent right away
"Here's my whole workflow, figure it out"
Result: Bad skills. The flow isn't tested. It's not based on YOUR actual process.

The Right Approach

1.
Work IN the loop first
Do the work alongside the agent manually
2.
Iterate until you're happy
Refine the process through real use
3.
THEN step out
"How can I take myself out of it?"
Keep it as simple as possible.
Don't add complexity until you actually need it.

The Right Approach

1.

2.
Iterate until you're happy
Refine the process through real use
3.
THEN step out
"How can I take myself out of it?"
Keep it as simple as possible.
Don't add complexity until you actually need it.

cd /Users/Ford/Github\ Repos/presentations/Skill-Issue && git add slides/08-how-skills-work.md slides/09-example-skill.md slides/10-occams-razor.md index.md && git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
checkpoint-4: Skills Deep Dive & Example

Created three new slides for the technical skills section:
- 08-how-skills-work.md: Explains the flow (model sees/acquires/reads skills) and file structure with progressive disclosure
- 09-example-skill.md: Shows Ford's actual skills setup with practical examples
- 10-occams-razor.md: Building skills the right way - work in the loop first, then step out

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"
